case.patient_narrative: My partner has end stage liver disease (alcoholic cirrhosis). Hepatic encephalopathy seems advanced. He is home, but because of his confusion and disorientation, he cant be left alone. He has been in and out of the hospital/ICU several times. His doctor told him he was dying, and when the doctor and I were alone he said it could be days, weeks, or months, but not likely a year. I feel lost and not sure what to expect. Financial and health POA are all set. What information in his records will be useful to determine how long does he have?

patient_question.phrase: has end stage liver disease (alcoholic cirrhosis). Hepatic encephalopathy seems advanced.
What information in his records will be useful to determine how long does he have?

case.clinician_question: Is there more specific information about the alcoholic cirrhosis with advanced Hepatic encephalopathy to predict his lifespan?
case.note_excerpt:
History of Present Illness: 47M with decompensated alcoholic and HCV cirrhosis, with history of hepatic encephalopathy, ascites, esophageal varices s/p banding and Budd-Chiari syndrome treated conservatively without anticoagulation, several recent admissions (last [**Date range (1) 29493**]), who presents now with altered mental status, hyponatremia, and [**Last Name (un) **].
Brief Hospital Course: A 47 year old male with PMH ETOH/HCV Cirrhosis complicated by hepatic encepthlopathy, varices, portal gastropathy, and ascites is admitted with toxic metabolic encephalopathy and acute renal failure.
# Goals of care: Patient admitted with progressive liver failure and hepatic encephalopathy refractory to traditional treatment. He then developed anuric renal failure and hepato-renal syndrome. Given that he was not a candidate for transplant and had exceeded the limits of medical therapy, a family meeting was held with his mother and HCP [**Name (NI) **] and goals of care were transitioned to comfort.
#Acute toxic-metabolic encephalopathy: related to hepatic encephalopathy, infectious work up was remarkable for positive U/A. He was treated with lactulose via NGT which was limited by vomiting, he did not have many bowel movements initially and goals of care were then transitioned to comfort measures and NGT was discontinued.
# Renal failure: patient admitted with creatinine at 3.1 above baseline 1.5 Urine Na:<10 consistend tiwht hepatorenal syndrome (HRS). He was treated for preseumed HRS with albumin, octreotide and mitodrine. GFR continued to decline and he became anuric. Goals of care were transitioned to comfort.
#Alcoholic/HCV Cirrhosis: complicated by hepatic encepthlopathy, varaces, portal gastropathy, and ascites. Not listed since he has yet to start ETOH abstinance program. Hepatology was consulted and did not think he was a candidate for transplant.
#Hyponatremia: Hypervoemic hyponatremia related to cirrhosis. Baseline sodium has been between 115-120. Patient admitted with Na 119, acute encephalopathy was thought to be unrelated to hyponatremia. He was placed on fluid restriction and sodium trended up to 131.
# Hyperkalemia: Initial labs showed elevated potassium (7.1) in the setting of hemolyzed labs, on re-check potassium is 6.0 and likely related to acute renal failure. After Keyexylate, K trended down to 4.0.
# Possible cellulitis: Exam remarkable for ill defined erythematous patches on the calves bilaterally. He was treated with cephalexin which was changed to ceftriaxone to cover urinary tract infection. Antibiotics were discontinued when goals of care were changed to comfort.
# Pyuria: U/A on admission was negative however repeat u/a following foley placement showed positive leuks and bactereia. He was started on ceftriaxone given acute encephalopathy as UTI could have contributed to confusion. Ceftriaxone was d/c when goals of care were changed to comfort.

Given that he was not a candidate for transplant and had exceeded the limits of medical therapy, a family meeting was held with his mother and HCP [**Name (NI) **] and goals of care were transitioned to comfort.
#Acute toxic-metabolic encephalopathy: related to hepatic encephalopathy, infectious work up was remarkable for positive U/A.

He was treated with lactulose via NGT which was limited by vomiting, he did not have many bowel movements initially and goals of care were then transitioned to comfort measures and NGT was discontinued.
# Renal failure: patient admitted with creatinine at 3.1 above baseline 1.5 Urine Na:<10 consistend tiwht hepatorenal syndrome (HRS).
He was treated for preseumed HRS with albumin, octreotide and mitodrine.
GFR continued to decline and he became anuric.
Goals of care were transitioned to comfort.
#Alcoholic/HCV Cirrhosis: complicated by hepatic encepthlopathy, varaces, portal gastropathy, and ascites.
Not listed since he has yet to start ETOH abstinance program.
Hepatology was consulted and did not think he was a candidate for transplant.
#Hyponatremia: Hypervoemic hyponatremia related to cirrhosis.
Baseline sodium has been between 115-120.
Patient admitted with Na 119, acute encephalopathy was thought to be unrelated to hyponatremia.
He was placed on fluid restriction and sodium trended up to 131.
# Hyperkalemia: Initial labs showed elevated potassium (7.1) in the setting of hemolyzed labs, on re-check potassium is 6.0 and likely related to acute renal failure.
After Keyexylate, K trended down to 4.0.
# Possible cellulitis: Exam remarkable for ill defined erythematous patches on the calves bilaterally.
He was treated with cephalexin which was changed to ceftriaxone to cover urinary tract infection.
Antibiotics were discontinued when goals of care were changed to comfort.
# Pyuria: U/A on admission was negative however repeat u/a following foley placement showed positive leuks and bactereia.
He was started on ceftriaxone given acute encephalopathy as UTI could have contributed to confusion.
Ceftriaxone was d/c when goals of care were changed to comfort.

case.patient_narrative: Took my 59 yo father to ER as his skin looked bruised. Ultrasound discovered he had an aortic aneurysm. He had a salvage repair (tube graft). Long surgery / recovery for couple hours then removed packs. why did they do this surgery????? After this time he spent 1 month in hospital now sent home

patient_question.phrase: he had an aortic aneurysm. He had a salvage repair (tube graft).
why did they do this surgery?????

case.clinician_question: Why did they perform the emergency salvage repair on him?
case.note_excerpt:
Brief Hospital Course: Mr. [**Known lastname **] was transferred to the [**Hospital1 18**] on [**2154-1-20**] for emergent repair of his ruptured thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm. He was taken immediately to the operating room where he underwent an emergent salvage repair of ruptured thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm with a 34-mm Dacron tube graft using deep hypothermic circulatory arrest. Please see operative note for details which included cardiac arrest x2. Postoperatively he was taken to the intensive care unit for monitoring with an open chest. He remained intubated and sedated on pressors and inotropes. On [**2154-1-22**], he returned to the operating room where he underwent exploration and chest closure. On [**1-25**] he returned to the OR for abd closure JP/ drain placement/ feeding jejunostomy placed at that time for nutritional support.
Wounds: thoracoabdominal wound healing well with exception of very small open area mid wound that is @1cm around and 1/2cm deep, no surrounding erythema. Packed with dry gauze and covered w/DSD-[**Hospital1 **]

case.patient_narrative: Hi Dr. My mom is 88 years old, no heart problems. She hit her head and was hospitalized. No intubation was done in ICU. Her blood count and pressure were normal, she could eat and was breathing on her own. My question is about the antibiotics she was given during her hospital stay. Were they necessary? Thank you,

patient_question.phrase: My question is about the antibiotics she was given during her hospital stay. Were they necessary?

case.clinician_question: Why was she given antibiotics during her hospital stay?
case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions:
At first, you were in the ICU, but when you improved, you were transferred to the regular neurology floor for care.
After someone hits their head, we watch them very closely for signs of worsened swelling or bleeding in the brain. All of your scans after the fall were relatively stable, and you made great progress with your level of alertness, memory, and physical activity in the days following the accident.
On [**2174-2-11**], it was noted that you were not holding your oxygen levels as high as we would like so a chest x-ray was done, and indicated that you were developing a pneumonia. We started IV antibiotics for this right away, and you improved.
Physical and occupational therapy saw you during this hospital stay, and recommended a short stay in rehab before you return to your home. At rehab, you will work to become stronger and safer on your own.

note_excerpt_sentences.sentence: Discharge Instructions:
At first, you were in the ICU, but when you improved, you were transferred to the regular neurology floor for care.
After someone hits their head, we watch them very closely for signs of worsened swelling or bleeding in the brain.
All of your scans after the fall were relatively stable, and you made great progress with your level of alertness, memory, and physical activity in the days following the accident.
On [**2174-2-11**], it was noted that you were not holding your oxygen levels as high as we would like so a chest x-ray was done, and indicated that you were developing a pneumonia.
We started IV antibiotics for this right away, and you improved.
Physical and occupational therapy saw you during this hospital stay, and recommended a short stay in rehab before you return to your home.
At rehab, you will work to become stronger and safer on your own.

case.patient_narrative: Hi Dr. My dad died from pneumonia. He was 55 years old, no heart problems and was hospitalized. He was intubated in the ICU, but Iâ€™m trying to understand why that was necessary. Was intubation a standard approach for pneumonia in someone his age? Thank you.

patient_question.phrase: Was intubation a standard approach for pneumonia in someone his age?

case.clinician_question: Why was the patient intubated?
case.note_excerpt:
History of Present Illness: Mr. [**Known lastname 52653**] is a 55 yo M with end-stage sarcoid on 3LNC at baseline, transferred from Radius with shortness of breath, tachypnea, hypoxia and fevers. According to reports from Radius has has been hypoxic for several days with O2 sats 91-92% on 100% NRB with desaturation to 86% with minimal exertion, patient refusing to come to hospital.
In the ED T99.2 BP 145/84 RR 20-30 HR 92-140 96% on 100%NRB. He was noted to be significantly hypoxic and tachypnic and was intubated due to concern for increasing work of breathing. He was given 2.5LNS, levofloxacin 750mg IV, cefepime 2g IV x1, decadron 10mg IV x1 and versed 2mg IV x1.

note_excerpt_sentences.sentence: History of Present Illness: Mr. [**Known lastname 52653**] is a 55 yo M with end-stage sarcoid on 3LNC at baseline, transferred from Radius with shortness of breath, tachypnea, hypoxia and fevers.
According to reports from Radius has has been hypoxic for several days with O2 sats 91-92% on 100% NRB with desaturation to 86% with minimal exertion, patient refusing to come to hospital.
He was noted to be significantly hypoxic and tachypnic and was intubated due to concern for increasing work of breathing.
He was given 2.5LNS, levofloxacin 750mg IV, cefepime 2g IV x1, decadron 10mg IV x1 and versed 2mg IV x1.

case.patient_narrative: Hi Dr. My dad is recovering from his recent stay for chronic congestive heart failure. No intubation was done in ICU and he was released to his home. His blood count and pressure is normal, he can eat and is breathing on his own. The question is about a CPAP machine used to help him with his respiration and oxygen levels. Was a CPAP useful to maintain a positive air flow or was it used for sleep apnea? Thank you,

patient_question.phrase: Was a CPAP useful to maintain a positive air flow or was it used for sleep apnea?

case.clinician_question: Why was he equipped with a CPAP machine?
case.note_excerpt: Discharge Instructions: Mr. [**Known lastname 17881**], You were admitted to the hospital for shortness of breath and low oxygen levels that were believed to be due to an exacerbation of your chronic congestive heart failure. You were temporarily admitted to the intensive care unit, so that you could receive supplemental oxygen through a positive-pressure mask. You were given medications to help removed excess fluid from your body, and your symptoms subsequently improved. Our orthopedic surgeons believed that you do not need to wear the collar for your cervical vertebral fracture. Your pacemaker was interrogated and found to be working appropriately. Through your course here, you were seen to have delirium on top of chronic dementia.

note_excerpt_sentences.sentence: Discharge Instructions: Mr. [**Known lastname 17881**],
You were admitted to the hospital for shortness of breath and low oxygen levels that were believed to be due to an exacerbation of your chronic congestive heart failure.
You were temporarily admitted to the intensive care unit, so that you could receive supplemental oxygen through a positive-pressure mask.
You were given medications to help removed excess fluid from your body, and your symptoms subsequently improved.
Our orthopedic surgeons believed that you do not need to wear the collar for your cervical vertebral fracture.
Your pacemaker was interrogated and found to be working appropriately.
Through your course here, you were seen to have delirium on top of chronic dementia.

case.patient_narrative: Hi Dr. My dad is 62 years old and was hospitalized. Intermittent intubation was done in ICU. My question is about the antibiotics he was given during his hospital stay. Were they necessary? Thank you,

patient_question.phrase: My question is about the antibiotics he was given during his hospital stay. Were they necessary?

case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions: Dear Mr. [**Known lastname **], You were brought to the hospital because of behavior changes at home. You became very agitated at the outside hospital and you required multiple medications for sedation and eventually needed to be intubated. Your intubation was complicated by a pneumonia and you were transferred to [**Hospital1 18**] for further management of your pneumonia and your mental status changes.
You were treated with a 7 day course of antibiotics for your pneumonia and you improved. You were seen by psychiatry and neurology. You again became very agitated and required IV sedation to control your agitation.
You then improved without additional medications.

case.patient_narrative: hi..my mother( age 61, residing home) is suffering from serious pancreatic infection...she was hospitalized fr 20 days in icu n now being rested ..but she is suffering from illness n pain...can u give some control measures to prevent it..it would so much helpful if any any information is provided..thanks

patient_question.phrase: she is suffering from illness n pain...can u give some control measures to prevent it

case.clinician_question: How is the patient expected to control the pain after being treated for pancreatitis?
case.note_excerpt:
History of Present Illness:
Pt was initially admitted to the OSH [**Date range (1) 29693**] for two episodes of epigastric pain and abnormal LFTs (AST 466 ALT 268). US and MRCP were reportedly normal. She was discharged with diagnosis of alcoholic hepatitis. That evening, pt called her GI doctor complaining of severe abdominal pain, n/v, tremulousness. She presented to the ED and was re-admitted. She was noted to be jaundiced, groggy, with a protuberant abdomen. WBC was 13.8, K 2.8, Bili 7.7, AST 324, ALT 370, alk phos 251, lipast 4877. Tox screen and EtOH levels were negative. Her abdomen became distended, tense, very tender, with no bowel sounds. She was transferred to the ICU for closer monitoring. She was treated with IVF and aggressive pain control with dilaudid 1mg IV q3. Additionally she was sedated on precedex and an ativan drip at 4mg/h. Pt was intubated for airway protection on the morning of [**10-14**]. CT of the abdomen revealed enlarged indistinct pancreas, extensive peripancreatic fluid consistent with severe pancreatitis and pancreatic necrosis, no loculated or drainable fluid collections or evidence of perforation. Also noted were small bilateral pleural effusions and moderate amount of free fluid in the deep pelvis.
Discharge Medications: 1. Polyvinyl Alcohol-Povidone 1.4-0.6 % Dropperette Sig: [**11-16**] Drops Ophthalmic PRN (as needed). 2. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day) as needed. 3. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for fever. 4. Loperamide 2 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 times a day) as needed. 5. Trazodone 50 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO HS (at bedtime) as needed. 6. Guaifenesin 100 mg/5 mL Syrup Sig: 5-10 MLs PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed. 7. White Petrolatum-Mineral Oil 42.5-56.8 % Ointment Sig: One (1) Appl Ophthalmic PRN (as needed). 8. Lorazepam 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed for anxiety. 9. Lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime) as needed. 10. Lisinopril 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 11. Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily). 12. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours). 13. Albuterol Sulfate 2.5 mg /3 mL (0.083 %) Solution for Nebulization Sig: One (1) Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours). 14. Ipratropium Bromide 0.02 % Solution Sig: One (1) Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours). 15. Amiodarone 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 16. Amlodipine 5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
17. Lasix 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day for 5 days.

case.clinician_question: How is the patient expected to control the pain after being treated for pancreatitis?
case.note_excerpt:
Brief Hospital Course:
# Pancreatitis: Possibly due to gallstones seen on CT and abdominal ultrasound. Patient's lipase was not elevated at the OSH but had radiological findings and abdominal pain. The patient's abdominal pain gradually resolved, initially as NPO with IVF/TPN and then advanced a regular diet. Pt will need ongoing monitoring of nutrition intake given her low albumin.
FOLLOW-UP: -Please make sure patient sees a gastroenterologist within 2 weeks after discharge for management of pancreatitis/pancreatic hemorrhage. We have arranged for follow-up for a gastroenenterologist at [**Hospital1 18**] but feel free to cancel this appointment and make arrangements with a different gastroenterologist. - Patient will need MRCP to look for signs of liver malignancy or infiltrative disease. - She should be reevaluated for G-tube placement in [**4-10**] weeks. - She should have repeat Contrast CT of the abdomen to evaluate for residual pancreatic pseudoaneurysm
Discharge Instructions:
The following changes were made to your medications: ADDED: - STARTED Daptomycin 350 mg iv every 24 hours until [**2109-6-11**] for 14 day course - STARTED Pantoprazole 40 mg by mouth daily - Remeron (mirtazapine) 7.5 mg by mouth at night CHANGED: - INCREASED frequency of vicodin from twice a day to every 6 hours as needed for pain REMOVED: - STOPPED Omeprazole (added pantprazole instead) - STOPPED Morphine liquid suspension (increased frequency of Vicodin) - STOPPED Gemfibrozil - STOPPED Valium - STOPPED Benadryl

Pt will need ongoing monitoring of nutrition intake given her low albumin.
FOLLOW-UP: -Please make sure patient sees a gastroenterologist within 2 weeks after discharge for management of pancreatitis/pancreatic hemorrhage.

case.patient_narrative: My wife just started coumadin on last friday due to 2 blood clots in one arm. No one knows whay she had the clots. She just came home yesterday from ICU and thinks it is ok to have a beer a day? What do you say?

patient_question.phrase: She just came home yesterday from ICU and thinks it is ok to have a beer a day? What do you say?

case.note_excerpt:
Brief Hospital Course:
# RUE DVT: Otherwise, her anticoagulation for her upper extremity DVT was continued (lovenox) with coumadin being held given plan by IP to exchange out the tracheostomy tube in early [**Month (only) 116**]. After IP decided that they were going to hold off on this procedure, Lovenox was discontinued and the patient was restarted on coumadin with daily INRs being checked.
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you while you were hospitalized at [**Hospital1 18**]. You were admitted to the hospital because your primary care doctor thought that you were retaining a lot of fluid. While you were in the emergency room, your pressures were low and you were initially admitted to the intensive care unit.
While on the medicine floor, your blood pressures remained in a good range. Your oxygenation levels were varying, and you required a return to the intensive care unit for one night. You have been doing better since then.
It will be VERY important that your oxygen levels stay in the range of 88-92%.

case.note_excerpt:
Brief Hospital Course: 61 yo female with hx morbid obesity, obesity-hypoventilation syndrome, obstructive sleep apnea complicated by pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale s/p trach who presents with abdominal pain, n/v and LE edema, found to be hypoxic with improved respiratory status s/p mechanical ventilation and diuresis.
# Abdominal pain - Unclear etiology, possibly related to constipation as she did report some improvement with BM's. CT abdomen and pelvis, EGD without any acute processes. We continued her on an agressive bowel regimen and simethicone for gas pains. Pt should be followed as an outpt for this chronic abdominal pain.
# RUE DVT - Pt was supratheraputic to 3.4, therefore coumadin was held for two days. She was restarted on her home dose of 7 mg of coumadin on [**5-22**]. On discharge her INR was 2.1. She will have her INR drawn on [**5-27**] and have the results faxed to Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3029**].

case.patient_narrative: my friend is home after being in ICU for 5 days with dx of severe sepsis. went to home then had an abscessed ruptured appendix back to hos now again home. the staff said she had a contagious UTI and administered oral antibiotics. she experienced no burning upon urination or discomfort. did they do a urinalysis...? what could be going on??? she has excellent medical insurance

patient_question.phrase: the staff said she had a contagious UTI
did they do a urinalysis...?

case.clinician_question: How was my friend diagnosed with a contagious UTI?
case.note_excerpt:
Brief Hospital Course:
1) Urinary Tract Infection/Concern for Urosepsis: The final culture results from the outside hosptial suggested that the patient had urinary tract infection caused by E coli. sensitive to all agents tested except E. coli. Despite the presumptive positive blood cultures final results would suggest the patient did not have a true bacteremia. All cultures taken at our institution were negative for growth at the time of discharge. At [**Hospital1 18**] the patient initially received a dose of vancomycin then was continued on pipercillin-tazobactam from [**Date range (1) 70177**] when final culture and sensitivity results from the urinary pathogen were obtained from the outside hospital and showed sensitivity to quinolones. Thus, patient was transitioned to oral ciprofloxacin therapy. She remained afebrile on this regimen and was discharged on day five of appropriate therapy to complete a nine additional days of antibiotic therapy for a total course of 14 days Regarding management of her neobladder the patient had a foley placed on presentation. Once perforation was essential ruled out by the CT cystogram urology approved her to return to her home schedule of clean intermittent cathterization and she was discharged to continue this.
Followup Instructions: You should schedule a follow-up with Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 365**] in urology in [**12-30**] weeks to discuss further management of your urology issues.
You need to schedule a follow up with your PCP, [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]. [**Last Name (STitle) 9449**], in [**12-30**] weeks to discuss this admission. The most important issues Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 9449**] needs to check on are to make sure your liver enzymes are improving (she should have the values from this hospitalization by that time)and to schedule an abdominal ultrasound to see if the abdominal fluid has resolved (this would probably best be obtained around the end of [**Month (only) 404**], four weeks after your discharge). Dr.[**Name (NI) 70178**] office can be reached at [**Telephone/Fax (1) 70179**].

case.patient_narrative: My mother whom is 53 and very very health consicous had a extreme onset of confusion Tuesday. She started having confusion, speech was highly impaired and it was very difficult for her to get accross anything. Again this was sudden. She would type on facebook and text and everything was a mess. She thought she needed to go to the eye doctor because she d been having eye heatlh problems which she has to receive shots for. She hasn t had a eye injection in three weeks now. When she arrived there she did not have an appointment they called an ambulance because she wasn t making any sense! She knew something was wrong and drove to the eye doctor with her hazards lights on. She arrived at the hospital ER and they immediately performed a cat scan and MRI which showed no signs of definite stroke . She arrived at hospital at 2:00 in afternoon. While in ER with her she did not know her name or any of childrens name! She didn t understand anything! She was so confused and complained of headache. She never slurred speach, she just was making sense. At 1:00 A.M. she still didn t know her name or her children s name. At 6:00 A.m. Wednesday she regained the ability to express her name and she knew who her children were. She remember s alot of what happend. Which I find amazing!! Like I said she excersises and eats right all the time!! So the doctor s have been all over the place on what happened! Neorolgist first suspected minnie stroke but now they all say different things. One said she had a urinary tract infection , one doctor said she did not, one doctor put her on blood thinner and one doctor took her off. Now they are saying that her potasium, magnesium and sodium were too low and this is what has caused all of this. She just got out of the hospital. I am confused because they seem to be!! My mother even pulled down her paints in the ER and used the bathroom on the floor. She would never do that!! So she was confused for 18 hours total not knowing who she was or who we were. Can you help with what may have happened with her?

patient_question.phrase: So she was confused for 18 hours total not knowing who she was or who we were. Can you help with what may have happened with her?

case.clinician_question: What did they find in the psych evaluation and what may have caused this episode?
case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay at [**Hospital1 18**]. You were transferred to our hospital for language problems and were found to have had a stroke. We think that you have a genetic disorder called MELAS that caused you to have a stroke-like episode. We started you on enzyme supplementation that may help improve the symptoms of MELAS (which stands for Mitochondrial myopathy, Encephalopathy, Lactic acidosis, and Stroke-like episodes). You were also treated for a URINARY TRACT INFECTION, HYPONATREMIA, HYPOMAGNESEMIA, and HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA.
We made the following changes to your medications: 1) We STOPPED your METFORMIN (you can no longer take this medication) 2) We STARTED you on COENZYME Q10 3) We STARTED you on L-CARNITINE 4) We STARTED you on CREATINE MONOPHOSPHATE 5) We STARTED you on L-ARGININE 6) We STARTED you on FISH OIL 7) We STARTED you on a MULTIVITAMIN
Because of your mitochondrial disease, you can never use the following medications: valproic acid (and derivatives), metformin, barbiturates, tetracyclines, aminoglycosies, chloramphenicol.
It you experience any of the below listed Danger Signs, please contact your doctor or go to the nearest Emergency Room.

We started you on enzyme supplementation that may help improve the symptoms of MELAS (which stands for Mitochondrial myopathy, Encephalopathy, Lactic acidosis, and Stroke-like episodes).
You were also treated for a URINARY TRACT INFECTION, HYPONATREMIA, HYPOMAGNESEMIA, and HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA.

2) We STARTED you on COENZYME Q10 3)
We STARTED you on L-CARNITINE 4) We STARTED you on CREATINE MONOPHOSPHATE 5) We STARTED you on L-ARGININE 6) We STARTED you on FISH OIL 7)
We STARTED you on a MULTIVITAMIN
Because of your mitochondrial disease, you can never use the following medications: valproic acid (and derivatives), metformin, barbiturates, tetracyclines, aminoglycosies, chloramphenicol.
It you experience any of the below listed Danger Signs, please contact your doctor or go to the nearest Emergency Room.

case.patient_narrative: My dad whom is 53 had a extreme onset of confusion Tuesday after a fall. He started having an eye pain, then confusion, speech was highly impaired and it was very difficult for him to get accross anything, severe headache. He arrived at the hospital ER and they immediately performed a cat scan and MRI which showed no signs of stroke . He arrived at hospital at 2:00 in afternoon. He didn t understand anything! He never slurred speach, he just was making sense. At 1:00 A.M. he still didn t know his name or his children s name. At 6:00 A.m. Wednesday he regained the ability to express his name and he knew who her children were. He remember s alot of what happend. Which I find amazing!! So the doctor s have been all over the place on what happened! Neorolgist first suspected minnie stroke but now they all say different things. One said she had a urinary tract infection , one doctor said she did not, one doctor put her on blood thinner and one doctor took her off. Now they are saying that her potasium, magnesium and sodium were too low and this is what has caused all of this. She just got out of the hospital. I am confused because they seem to be!! So he was confused for 18 hours total not knowing who he was or who we were. It all started with the fall.... Can you help with what may have happened with him?

patient_question.phrase: So he was confused for 18 hours total not knowing who he was or who we were.
Can you help with what may have happened with him?

case.clinician_question: What did they find in the psych evaluation and what may have caused this episode?
case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions: It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay here at [**Hospital1 18**].
You were admitted for confusion called hepatic encephalopathy. This is a result of build up of toxins in your body that your liver is unable to clear. This is a result of not taking enough lactulose at home to have three bowel movements per day.
In addition, you were found to have a persistent UTI. This is a result of not finishing your course of antibiotics at home. You are being given a new prescription for a second course of antibiotics. Please take this antibiotic course in its entirity.
The following changes were made to your medication list: START amoxicillin for 9 days

case.clinician_question: What did they find in the psych evaluation and what may have caused this episode?
case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions: You were admitted to the hospital with confusion, low magnesium, potassium, and calcium. In the ED, you had a seizure that was most likely due to your low electrolytes and also alcohol withdrawal. Your low electrolytes were attributed to your chronic diarrhea, alcohol use, and poor nutrition. A CT scan of your head did not show any acute problems. Our neurology colleagues saw you and recommended correction of your electrolytes and abstinence from alcohol. You were seen by PT, OT and social work who are concerned about your ability to care for yourself at home. You are being discharged to a rehab facility to help you regain your strength and ensure a safe return home.
The following changes were made in your medications: START Magnesium Oxide 400 mg twice daily with breakfast and dinner START Amlodipine 5 mg by mouth daily START Folic Acid 1 mg daily START Thiamine 100 mg daily START Vitamin D 50,000 units weekly (on Saturdays) for 6 weeks
DISCONTINUE Magnesium Chloride
You may changed the Magnesium Oxide to Magnesium Chloride if you continue to have difficulties tolerating the medication.

You may changed the Magnesium Oxide to Magnesium Chloride if you continue to have difficulties tolerating the medication.

My mother lost 100 pounds by eating everything right and excercising all the time. She has never swayed from her goal of being fit for the rest of her life since two years ago. case.clinician_question: What did they find in the psych evaluation and what may have caused this episode?
case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions: Weigh yourself every morning, [**Name8 (MD) 138**] MD if weight > 3 lbs. Adhere to 2 gm sodium diet
You were admitted to the hospital because your sodium, potassium, magnesium, and phosphorous levels were very low. You were given fluids and electrolyte repletion to which you responded quite well. Your diuretics (lasix and HCTZ) were stopped and you were started on another diuretic name spironolactone which should not affect your electrolytes as much. In addition, it is likely that you were quite dehydrated and may have an abnormal level of the hormone aldosterone. The level of this hormone was sent but results have not returned. You should follow up on this with your primary care doctor who will receive the results.
In addtion, you were found to have a urinary tract infection with E.coli that was sensitive to ciprofloxacin. Treatment was started in the hospital but you should complete a total 7 day course of antibiotics which will last three and a half days after discharge. You should not take cipro at the same time as any vitamins (iron, calcium) as these medications may bind to the cipro and cause it to be less effective. You may take the medications at seperate times throughout the day.

case.patient_narrative: I am 53 yrs old and I have gone under three courses of radiation therapy already. I have been left with a poor memory and find it difficult to follow instructions. I have been referred to the ICU neurology dept for help...but I am worried how much help they can give me?

patient_question.phrase: I have been referred to the ICU neurology dept for help...but I am worried how much help they can give me?

case.clinician_question: Why was she referred to the ICU neurology department?
case.note_excerpt:
History of Present Illness:
On neurologic review of systems, the patient denies headaches or lightheadedness. She endorses confusion. Denies difficulty with producing or comprehending speech. Denies loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, vertigo, tinnitus, hearing difficulty, dysarthria, or dysphagia. Denies muscle weakness. Denies loss of sensation. Denies bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. Endorses difficulty with gait.
Discharge Instructions: It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay at the [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 3867**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]. You presented with problems regarding your thinking, weight loss and latterly problems with [**Location (un) 1131**], writing and walking. You were found to have mild right sided weakness and subtle coordination problems on the right in addition to reduced vision on your right visual field. You had an MRI of your brain that showed several masses in your [**Last Name (un) **] with associated swelling and you were started on a medication called dexamethasone to reduce this swelling and keppra an anti-seizure medication to reduce the risk of having seizures. You had no seizures during your hospital stay. After dexamethasone was started, your examination improved. You also had a CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis which showed a left lung mass and enlarged glands in the lungs in addition to a likely tumor deposit in your right pelvis. You were assessed by radiation oncology, hematology/oncology and neuro-oncology. You underwent 3 courses of whole brain radiotherapy from [**Date range (1) 29694**] and had a biopsy of the lung mass on [**1-8**] and results are pending. You will have 2 more sessions of brain radiotherapy and have follow-up with thoracic oncology and neuro-oncology. You had a much improved examination by discharge and the weakness had resolved and there was still evidence of some subtle [**Location (un) 1131**] and writing problmes in addition to a subtle decrease in vision predominantly involving the lower right portion of your right eye visual field. You will be started on a taper of the dexamethasone (a steroid) once your whole brain radiotherapy has finished on Monday [**2194-1-13**]. Details of this are below. You have follow-up with thoracic oncology and neuro-oncology.

case.patient_narrative: hello, all doctors i am here for my dad is suffering from liver cirrhosis and stone in gall bladder, a few days back he felt unconcious then we took him to hospitol then he was kept in ICU for 10 days then after treatment he came back to censes, in the mean process aprox 1 and half litre water pumped from stomuch and now again there is sign of swelling and filling of water in stomuch then again we consult our doctor they suggested for liver transplant,here now I am asking from you people that what is the best and proper way to cure hime=.

patient_question.phrase: there is sign of swelling and filling of water in stomuch
what is the best and proper way to cure hime=.

case.clinician_question: Is he getting any treatment for the swelling?
case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions: You were transferred to [**Hospital1 69**] with a complaint of abdominal pain. CT scan, abdominal ultrasound, MRI, and EGD did not show a clear cause for your pain, but ruled out conditions that would require emergent intervention. Your pain improved over the course of your stay.
While you were here, you were noted to have a very low hematocrit (red blood cell level). There was no evidence that you were actively bleeding. You received 3 units of packed RBCs to raise your hematocrit to a safer level.
In addition, you were noted to have significant swelling in your legs, groin and abdomen. This swelling is due to excess fluid that accumulates because of your liver disease. We have made changes to your diuretic regimen that we hope will help to decrease swelling.
We have made the following changes to your medication regimen: - INCREASE DOSE of lactulose as needed to ensure [**2-26**] bowel movements daily (OK to take as often as every 1-2 hours) - BEGIN TAKING Lasix (furosemide) 40 mg by mouth twice daily - BEGIN TAKING Aldactone (spironolactone) 50 mg by mouth daily - TAKE AS NEEDED Ultram (tramadol) 50 mg every 8 hours as needed for pain - TAKE AS NEEDED Tylenol (acetominophen) 500 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain
Please keep your follow up appointment as directed below.

note_excerpt_sentences.sentence: Discharge Instructions: You were transferred to [**Hospital1 69**] with a complaint of abdominal pain.
CT scan, abdominal ultrasound, MRI, and EGD did not show a clear cause for your pain, but ruled out conditions that would require emergent intervention.
Your pain improved over the course of your stay.
While you were here, you were noted to have a very low hematocrit (red blood cell level).
There was no evidence that you were actively bleeding.
You received 3 units of packed RBCs to raise your hematocrit to a safer level.
In addition, you were noted to have significant swelling in your legs, groin and abdomen.
This swelling is due to excess fluid that accumulates because of your liver disease.
We have made changes to your diuretic regimen that we hope will help to decrease swelling.

We have made the following changes to your medication regimen: - INCREASE DOSE of lactulose as needed to ensure [**2-26**] bowel movements daily (OK to take as often as every 1-2 hours) - BEGIN TAKING Lasix (furosemide) 40 mg by mouth twice daily - BEGIN TAKING Aldactone (spironolactone) 50 mg by mouth daily - TAKE AS NEEDED Ultram (tramadol) 50 mg every 8 hours as needed for pain - TAKE AS NEEDED Tylenol (acetominophen) 500 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain
Please keep your follow up appointment as directed below.

case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions: You were admitted to the hospital after presenting with abdominal pain and being found to have a blood clot in the portal vein of your liver and small bowel. You were unable to be anticoagulated for this clot because you developed a bleed in your bowel. You were followed closely by the Surgery and Hepatology service. You were treated with blood transfusions for your bleed. Your hematocrit stabilized and you required no further blood transfusions. You are completing a 14 day course of antibiotics to treat the inflammation in your GI tract caused by the blood clot.
You were found to have a pleural effusion caused by your liver disease. You underwent a thoracentesis to treat this fluid accumulation. You are continuing on diuretics, lasix and spironolactone to help prevent a reoccurrence of this effusion.
During your hospitalization you also developed an irregular and fast heart rate called atrial fibrillation. You were treated with a medication called diltiazem to slow your heart rate. You are being discharged on telemetry for further monitoring of your heart rate and adjustment of your medications.
Your diuretics spironolactone and lasix were briefly held. You have been restarted on lasix 10mg daily and spironolactone 50mg daily. Your urine output and weight will continued to be monitored and adjusted as needed.
You will need to follow up with Hepatology as scheduled below. You are being discharged to a acute rehabilitation facility for continued physical therapy and medication adjustment.

I was recently admitted to the hospital and had two bags of fluids ,morphine and xrays for what I was told was bacterial bronchitis and was given a Zpack and steroids to take. I'm on my 4th pill and I feel I'm getting worse. The cough is bad, im coughing up dark green and yellow mucus. I have a major headache that won't go away. Im also running a fever off and on... Could this be something else or have turned into something worse?

case.clinician_question: What is the expcted course of her recovery from bronchitis?
case.note_excerpt:
Brief Hospital Course: ___ F h/o COPD p/w worsening SOB x 3 wks, now with cough productive of green sputum and CTA indicating bronchitis and small airway infection. Ms. ___ was seen in ED and had CTA chest negative for PE as well as negative troponins in the setting of chest heaviness. She was admitted due to persistent SOB and treated with PO prednisone for a COPD exacerbation. She was also started on a five-day course of azithromycin for bronchitis/small airway infection.
ACTIVE DIAGNOSES
Sputum was collected in efforts to test for MAC via AFB smear and culture, but the sample was not processed as expected. Sputum cytology was negative for malignant cells (although the yield is low). On CTA chest, there was an opacity in the periphery of the right middle lobe which was not specifically commented upon in the radiology report. Repeat CT chest imaging in ___ weeks is advised. If lungs have not cleared in the interim, further evaluation for MAC pulmonary infection ("Lady ___ syndrome") and malignancy is advised. Patient was scheduled for outpatient follow-up with Pulmonary Medicine.
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES * Pt will be discharged with home ___ services. Please do oxygen saturation monitoring as an outpatient and refer to pulmonary rehab as appropriate. * Pt should follow-up with Pulmonary Medicine as an outpatient. Please repeat chest CT in ___ weeks as an outpatient to assess interval change. If lung findings have not cleared in the interim, further evaluation for MAC pulmonary infection ("Lady ___ syndrome") and malignancy is advised (see below). * Sputum was collected to test for AFB smear/culture, but the specimen did not get processed as expected. If repeat chest CT is abnormal, consider testing sputum for AFB smear and culture to assess for MAC pulmonary infection ("___ syndrome"). * Given history of smoking and COPD, family history of lung cancer, and finding of peripheral opacity in right lung on CTA, sputum cytology was tested and returned negative for malignant cells. Please note that sputum cytology has a low yield for abnormal cells, and further work-up would be necessary to definitively rule out malignancy if repeat chest CT remains abnormal after pulmonary/small airway infection clears. * Also of note, pt is on a variety of psychiatric medications at home, including bupropion, quetiapine, venlafaxine, and topiramate. This combination of medications increases risk of serotonin syndrome. Optimization/simplification of psychiatric medication regimen as an outpatient is encouraged. * Please consider whether estradiol and progesterone remain necessary and, if so, determine their expected duration. Discontinue when possible so as to avoid risk for blood clot and other complications.
Discharge Instructions:
Please see the attached medication list for changes to your home medication regimen. You will have short courses of azithromycin and prednisone to finish at home. Other medications include eye drops and nystatin mouth solution. Also, you have a prescription for a nicotine patch. We strongly encourage you to continue avoiding cigarettes, as you have done while hospitalized. Smoking cessation is an important step toward improving your health.
Please follow up with Pulmonary Medicine according to the appointment list below. You should have a repeat chest CT scan in ___ weeks.

case.patient_narrative: Yes, I just returned from the hospital! The doctors did a great job! My main Complaint was Severe Chest pains on my left side, Radiating from my Sternum up and around my upper portion of my left chest, close to my collar bone, then down the left side of my body! Stopping at the bottom portion of the left side of my chest! They drew Blood samples, did an EKG, ran X-Rays And said I was not having a Heart attack! Which I Trust and Believe is True! Even after all the Pain Medication they gave me in the hospital, I had no relief from the Severe pain! I am not worried about the pain, as much, as to what this Ailment might be? I also have Numbness from my Elbow down to my finger tips! I have not had any recent Injuries! No Severe Coughing fits? I have quit smoking about a month ago? I have no Dizziness, nor am I lightheaded! Just the Severe Pain on the left side of my chest, with numbness from my left elbow down to my finger tips! Any Suggestions, of what it could be?

patient_question.phrase: Just the Severe Pain on the left side of my chest, with numbness from my left elbow down to my finger tips! Any Suggestions, of what it could be?

case.clinician_question: Can her ongoing severe chest pain be explained by anything found during her hospital visit?

case.clinician_question: Was it antibiotics or foods that caused cholecystitis?
case.note_excerpt:
Brief Hospital Course: Ms. ___ is a ___ with T2DM and reactive airway disease who was admitted to ___ on ___ with RUQ pain, nausea, and vomiting. RUQ ultrasound revealed gallstones/sludge but no findings of acute cholecystitis despite clinical ___ sign. CT abd/pelvis was notable for a 4mm gallstone within the cystic duct resulting in acute cholecystitis. On ___ she was taken to the operating room and underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Intraoperative findings were significant for a gangrenous gallbladder that did fall back into the peritoneal cavity before removal as well as significant inflammation. Please see operative report for details of this procedure. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was extubated upon completion. Given findings of gangrenous cholecystitis patient was started on a 4 day course of unasyn ___, switched to augmentin ___ (completed ___.
The patient was transferred to the surgical floor hemodynamically stable. Her vital signs were routinely monitored and she remained afebrile and hemodynamically stable with PO metoprolol. She was initially given IV fluids postoperatively, which were discontinued when she was tolerating PO's. Her diet was advanced as tolerated, which she tolerated without abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. She was voiding adequate amounts of urine without difficulty after foley removal. She was encouraged to mobilize out of bed and ambulate as tolerated, which she was able to do independently. Her pain level was routinely assessed and well controlled at discharge with an oral regimen (prn oxycodone) as needed Discharge Instructions:
PAIN MANAGEMENT: o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more medicine at one time than prescribed. o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your pain gets too severe. o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your surgeon has said its okay. o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of pain medicine.

Discharge Instructions:
___ were admitted to ___ with sudden-onset left flank pain in the setting of being treated for bronchitis. ___ had a chest x-ray and rib x-ray while ___ were admitted, which did not show any pneumonia or rib fractures. ___ also had a V/Q scan (an imaging test to evaluate for conditions such as blood clots in the lungs), which was indeterminate. case.patient_narrative: Hi, I have been experiencing some dizziness the last couple of days...not spinning, just feeling unstable on the feet, sometimes I feel like I step onto an uneven ground and kind of wobble a little...occasionally, I also feel sudden tingling/numb in the lower back of the head...the dizziness can last for hours but mostly when I am standing up and walking around...I was at the emergency room twice with some signs of heart attack (chest pain) but tests came back normal except with some test that indicated a potential insufficient blood to the heart...(very mild case and may not been conclusive according to my cardiologist). I am otherwise very healthy with a little of thyroid issue and no family history of heart issue...I have continued with my exercise routine (cardio and strength training) and have not created any problems....Could I possibly had a mini stroke that they did not get picked up on?? I will need to travel (fly) for work and I am a little concern....thanks

case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the ___ Neurology Service on ___ for further workup of your episode of imbalance, blurry vision, and neck discomfort. A CT of your head did not show any acute bleed or infarct, but did show acute-on-chronic sinusitis. An MRI of your head did not show any evidence of a bleed or infarct either.
As part of your workup a chest x-ray and EKG were completed. The chest x-ray did not show any acute process with your lungs or heart. The EKG shows a left bundle branch block in your heart, which may represent a previous myocardial infarction.
Your labwork included cardiac enzymes (to evaluate for myocardial ischemia) which were negative. Your ammonia level was normal (high levels can cause brain dysfunction). Your cholesterol was 189, triglycerides 95, HDL (good cholesterol) 55, LDL (bad cholesterol) 115, and hemoglobin A1c (measure of blood sugar over time) 5.9%. A lamictal level was sent off, but not available at the time of discharge. You will be notified if this level was abnormal.
The left bundle branch block seen on EKG is new from a previous EKG in ___. To further evaluate this new finding, a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was completed. The results of this study showed hyperdynamic left ventricle with moderate resting outflow obstruction, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation, mild pulmonary hypertension. This result is not immediately concerning and no intervention is necessary at this time. Please stay well hydrated to avoid any symptoms that may surface such as lightheadedness or dizziness. You will also followup with a cardiologist.
The symptoms you were experiencing yesterday may be related to medication use or a transient ischemic attack (TIA). Your labwork and imaging studies are not suggestive of a stroke or other acute neurological issue.
You were started on aspirin 325mg daily and also simvastatin 20mg daily. The simvastatin was started to lower your cholesterol (goal <100). You should continue all of your home medications in addition to the new prescriptions.
On your flight to ___, you should get up to walk and stretch several times. Also remember to take your aspirin.
You have a followup appointment with Dr. ___, as seen below. You also have a followup appointment scheduled with Dr. ___, Cardiologist, as seen below. You should also followup with your primary care physician within the next couple of weeks.

This result is not immediately concerning and no intervention is necessary at this time.
Please stay well hydrated to avoid any symptoms that may surface such as lightheadedness or dizziness.
You will also followup with a cardiologist.
The symptoms you were experiencing yesterday may be related to medication use or a transient ischemic attack (TIA).
Your labwork and imaging studies are not suggestive of a stroke or other acute neurological issue.
You were started on aspirin 325mg daily and also simvastatin 20mg daily.
The simvastatin was started to lower your cholesterol (goal <100).
You should continue all of your home medications in addition to the new prescriptions.
On your flight to ___, you should get up to walk and stretch several times.
Also remember to take your aspirin.
You have a followup appointment with Dr. ___, as seen below.
You also have a followup appointment scheduled with Dr. ___, Cardiologist, as seen below.
You should also followup with your primary care physician within the next couple of weeks.

case.patient_narrative: Iâ€™m having a lot of lower abdominal pressure and pressure in my rear that is very uncomfortable. Few days ago, I was involved in car accident. I was rear-ended. I went to the ER and they did a CT Scan. They said everything was ok but I still have that pain. Is that normal?

patient_question.phrase: Few days ago, I was involved in car accident
I still have that pain. Is that normal?

case.clinician_question: Is it expected for the patient to have lower abdominal and rear pain a few days after the accident?
case.note_excerpt:
Brief Hospital Course: ___ yo man w/ past medical history of lung cancer s/p pneumonectomy, MI, CVA, who presented w/ possible syncope leading to MVC. Family requesting transfer to ___ where he receives his care, we facilitated this prior to completing our own workup. Of note on transfer, intial imaging did not show any acute intracranial process, c-spine fractures, or signficant intra-thoracoabdominal injury. He was noted on final read of CT torso this morning to have L1 compression fracture of vertebral body, likely old per radiology, but he did endorse low back pain on admission.
# Low back pain: As described above, CT imaging showed L1 vertebral body compression fracture, likely old. Pt also endorsing back pain near L1, although his pain is somewhat lateral to the right along the paraspinous muscles as opposed to midline at the spinous process. He does not have any new neuro deficits, or trouble moving his bladder or bowels decreasing suspicion for cord impingement. This will need to be evaluated further on transfer.
Discharge Instructions:
You were brought to ___ after an automobile collision during ___ you might have lost consciousness. You were evaluated for possible injuries, of which several were found: 1. Bruise R ear 2. Laceration to your finger 3. Possible L1 vertebral compression fracture, although this may be an old injury based on the CT scan interpretation by our radiologits.
The remainder of your radiology imaging did not show any fractures, although there were several irregularities w/ your kidneys and your aorta that we suggest you have evaluated. These have been detailed in your transfer documentation, and you should ask your physicians at ___ what kind of follow up evaluation and care you will need.
We also evaluated you for the loss of consciousness. Although our work-up was not complete at your time of transfer, we did determine that your heart rhythm on ECG was slower than normal, and that you had several premature atrial contractions. We evaluated a blood lab called troponin that shows possible heart ischemia, this was negative.
You requested a transfer to ___ where you receive your care. The doctors at ___ agreed to this transfer, and you are being sent there to finish your in-hospital evaluation for syncope and any injuries you might have from the car accident.

case.patient_narrative: I was diagnosed with very low RBC count of 5.8 and an iron level of 2. The docs in the ER were amazed I was even talking. I had felt ill for many months. I recieved 4 units of blood. Wow, do I feel better. Im not bleeding internally, so why did this happen to me?

patient_question.phrase: I was diagnosed with very low RBC count of 5.8 and an iron level of 2.
why did this happen to me?

case.clinician_question: Why were her hemoglobin and iron levels low?
case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after you presented in liver clinic with evidence of worsening belly fluid, chest pain, and low blood counts.
While here at the hospital you were evaluated with blood work and imaging. You were found to have low blood counts, so a series of labs and imaging was done to see if there was any evidence of bleeding. You were also tested for a variety of conditions that might be involved with breaking down blood cells. These tests returned negative, suggesting that your low blood counts were consistent with the your ongoing liver disease. You were given blood transfusions to treat your low blood counts, and the transfusions went well when you were premedicated with a medication called Tylenol and Lyrica.
We would like you to follow-up with Dr. ___ to look at your blood counts. There may be consideration of a further study called a capsule study should you continue to have blood count drops. You may also need to receive iron infusions outside the hospital.
You also had symptoms of chest pain when you were admitted. You were tested for heart attack with electrocardiogram, echocardiography, and lab work. The tests were negative. There was however some concern regarding some of your right sided heart function, so your ongoing fluid/diuretic management will be very important. We would like you to follow-up with Dr. ___ restarting your home diuretics and nadolol.
There was also ongoing concern regarding your kidney function, so your home diuretics were held while you were in the hospital. We would like you to follow-up with Dr. ___ starting your home diuretics.
When you go home it will be very important for you to take your previous medications as prescribed, excepting the furosemide, spironolactone, and nadolol. You may resume your home diabetic control.

You were admitted to the hospital for right-sided abdominal and back pain. A CT scan done in the emergency department showed new masses in your liver and nodules in your lungs. case.patient_narrative: I went to the ED for a stiff neck i have for two days now. I tried to tell the PA ED that I have cervical problems and also several spinal problems. I was prescribed Valium and steroids and sent home. I was wondering if i should go to VA ED to get MRI on cervical spine? My neck hurts into the brain, I have Migraine history for the last two years only, off and on. I am on preventative meds for that. Neck stiffness with migraine, earache, all on left side.

patient_question.phrase: I went to the ED for a stiff neck i have for two days now.
I was wondering if i should go to VA ED to get MRI on cervical spine?

case.clinician_question: Does she need an MRI for her neck stiffness?
case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions:
WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED? -You were admitted to the hospital due to bad you had head and neck pain.
WHAT HAPPENED IN THE HOSPITAL? -You had CT imaging of the head which was reassuring and showed no evidence of bleeding. -You were given pain medications to control your pain. -You were started on low-dose amitriptyline for better head pain control. -You had an MRI of your upper spine which showed significant swelling as well as strained ligaments and muscles. -You were evaluated by the neurology team who believed to her head pain was caused by the injuries above. -Your also evaluated by the physical therapy team. They recommended getting out of bed as many as 3 times per day in order to help you get better. -You were given a soft collar to wear around her neck. This should help support her neck muscles. - You were unable to urinate so we had to place a Foley Catheter, which a urologist will remove at the appointment on ___ if you are able to urinate on your own at that point(see below)
WHAT SHOULD YOU DO AT HOME? -You should follow-up with Dr. ___ at 3:15 ___ on ___, ___. Her office is located at ___. The office phone is ___. -You should continue to take all of your medications at home. -You should watch out for any worsening weakness in your legs or arms.

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO AT HOME?
-You should follow-up with Dr. ___ at 3:15 ___ on ___, ___.
Her office is located at ___.
The office phone is ___.

-You should watch out for any worsening weakness in your legs or arms.

case.patient_narrative: I recently took a HPT and the result was positive, but other than fatigue I feel like Iâ€™ve had no pregnancy symptoms. Also my home life has been very stressful. Last week I was in the ER for a migraine and the doctor wanted to test my urine for pregnancy and protein. The doctor called me back 24 hrs later and asked me to make an appt for prenatal care but did not tell me whether or not the pregnancy test or protein test came back positive or negative. I don t know whether to tell my husband we might be expecting or not and I do not want to get my hopes up either. We really want to have a baby. So, I guess what Iâ€™m asking is in a doctorâ€™s opinion do I start getting my hopes up or should I be worried that something is wrong?

patient_question.phrase: Last week I was in the ER for a migraine and the doctor wanted to test my urine for pregnancy and protein.
So, I guess what Iâ€™m asking is in a doctorâ€™s opinion do I start getting my hopes up

case.clinician_question: Was her pregnancy confirmed?
case.note_excerpt:
History of Present Illness: ___ yo female with history of ETOH abuse who recently relapsed after being sober for ___ years. She was reportedly in police custody and she states the officer threw her into a cell and she lost her balance and struck her head and had LOC. She was evaluated at ___ where they initially read her Head CT as negative and discharged her. Upon review it was noted that she had a left occipital, depressed skull fracture. She complains of left occiput pain/tenderness. She has had photophobia and hyperacussis since a concussion 4 weeks ago sustained from an MVC. Currently she denies any visual changes or HA. Of note she was also found to have a positive pregnancy test at the OSH and she states her LMP was 4 weeks ago.
Brief Hospital Course: Mrs. ___ was admitted on ___ to the ICU for close monitoring of her occipital skull fracture. In the ED her HCG was positive. OB was consulted for recommendations of meds and if the patient is able to continue her home meds which are catergory C meds. OB sated to continue home meds, and ok to use narcotics if needed. Please refer to the OB note for further specific details. On ___, the patient remained neurologically and hemodynamically stable. A repeat head CT was not obtained in the setting of a stable neuro exam and pregnancy. The patient expressed readiness to be discharged home. All narcotics were stopped and given Tylenol prn. OB recommend a ultrasound outpatient as soon as possible. Social work was consulted for assistance in living situation and also assistance with locating a detox center. However, the patient is familiar with a detox center and scheduled an appointment for first thing tomorrow morning. She stated she will like to get better for her babies. The patient was discharged in stable conditions, all discharge instructions and follow up were given prior to discharge.
Discharge Medications:Medications: 1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain Do not exceed more than 4 grams in 24hrs. 2. Amphetamine-Dextroamphetamine XR 30 mg PO DAILY 3. FLUoxetine 80 mg PO DAILY 4. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 5. Gabapentin 800 mg PO QID 6. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO ONCE pain Duration: 1 Dose

case.patient_narrative: my 56 year old sister was hospitalized with multiple fractures the other day after she was involved in a car crash. Her xray showed atelectasis in the left lower lobe. I was wondering how I should follow up on this because she is still experiencing chest pain that comes and goes while at rest.

patient_question.phrase: I was wondering how I should follow up on this because she is still experiencing chest pain that comes and goes while at rest.

case.clinician_question: What should she do for her ongoing chest pain?
case.note_excerpt:
CXR ___: Mild left basilar opacity likely reflects atelectasis although underlying pneumonia is difficult to exclude.
Brief Hospital Course: ___ ejected from MV at 40 mph. Patient was confused on scene but speaking, significant head laceration noted. Patient was intubated for confusion/agitation and received 150 fent, 2mg midaz, 75 ketamine en-route to hospital. Patient was hemodynamically stable upon evaluation. Injuries include T4 burst Fx, T5 osteophyte Fx,T1-T4 SP fx, Rt 1st rib Fx with displacement, extensive scalp lac, right distal clavicular fx. Her scalp laceration was stapled in the ED. Ortho Spine recommended nonoperative management w/ cervical collar on at all times, ___ brace while out of bed. On hospital day 0, patient was started on phenobarbital taper and transitioned to precede gtt. MRI Head negative, MRI spine showed posterior soft tissue edema c/w ligamentous injury from C4-T5, T4 burst fracture w/ mild retropulsion without cord compression. CTA Neck negative for vascular injury. She spike a fever to 102.5, blood, urine and mini BAL sent (BAL grew 3+ GNRs later found to be Moraxella catarrhalis). Her Hct was down to 20.5 and she was transfused 1U pRBC, her Hct responded to 25.2. By Hospital day 2, patient was moving all extremities and following instructions and so she was extubated. Patient was able to ventilate well on face mask afterwards. On Hospital Day 3, patient passed her speech/swallow evaluation and so the NGT was removed. Psychiatry was consulted for passive SI and depression, recommended starting Citalopram 40 mg QD. Her Foley was removed and she voided. On Hospital Day 4 the patient was transferred to the floor where she continued to work w/ physical therapy, which recommended rehab.
On the floor, she continued tolerate a normal diet, was voiding independently but required pain control titration. She was started on Bactrim for a 7 day course for her M. catarrhalis CAP and initiated on Macrobid for a UTI as defined by a UA.
By day of discharge, her pain was well controlled, she was eating, voiding, and eliminating independently, and her cough was controlled with inhalers and antibiotics.
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after being involved in a MVC. You sustained fractures to your cervical and thoracic spine, in addition to a rib fracture and a right clavicle fracture. You were fitted for a special brace for stabilization of your neck and spine. You also sustained a laceration to your scalp which was staples. You had an airway placed to assist with your breathing and you were monitored in the intensive care unit. Because of your injuries, you were evaluated by the Spine and orthopedic services. You were evaluated by physical therapy and recommendations made for discharge to a rehabilitation center to further improve your mobililty. You are being discharged with the following instructions:
** Rib Fracture * Your injury caused a right 1st rib fracture which can cause severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of the pain. * You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and notify your physician. * Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures. In order to decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 times every hour while awake. This will help expand the small airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that pool in the lungs. * You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and deep breathing. * Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short periods may ease the pain. * Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid and fiber intake if possible. * Do NOT smoke * Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn). * Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation around your ribs (crepitus).
- Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the Emergency Department for any of the following: * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness. * New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze. * If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your medications. * You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing. * You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a bowel movement. * You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your urine, or experience a discharge. * Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or back. * You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius. * Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern you.

Brief Hospital Course: ___ ejected from MV at 40 mph. Patient was confused on scene but speaking, significant head laceration noted.
Patient was intubated for confusion/agitation and received 150 fent, 2mg midaz, 75 ketamine en-route to hospital.
Patient was hemodynamically stable upon evaluation.
Injuries include T4 burst Fx, T5 osteophyte Fx,T1-T4 SP fx, Rt 1st rib Fx with displacement, extensive scalp lac, right distal clavicular fx.

MRI

On Hospital Day 4 the patient was transferred to the floor where she continued to work w/ physical therapy, which recommended rehab.
On the floor, she continued tolerate a normal diet, was voiding independently but required pain control titration.
She was started on Bactrim for a 7 day course for her M. catarrhalis CAP and initiated on Macrobid for a UTI as defined by a UA.
By day of discharge, her pain was well controlled, she was eating, voiding, and eliminating independently, and her cough was controlled with inhalers and antibiotics.

You were admitted to the hospital after being involved in a MVC.
You sustained fractures to your cervical and thoracic spine, in addition to a rib fracture and a right clavicle fracture.
You were fitted for a special brace for stabilization of your neck and spine.

This will help expand the small airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that pool in the lungs.

* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short periods may ease the pain.
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid and fiber intake if possible.
* Do NOT smoke *
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn).
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation around your ribs (crepitus).

case.patient_narrative: My husband has symptons of lighted headedness and slightly dizzy. A week ago he was in the emergency room because he was weak and couldn t walk, got nauseated and broke out in a sweat. (Taken by ambulance to emergency room.) Stayed overnight in the hospital. They did a CT scan of head to determine if he had a stroke and that came back negative not even a mini stroke. Also had chest exray, EKG, Echocardiogram and lots of blood tests. All came back negative and he still is not 100 per cent. Was tested for Lymes Disease and that also was negative. He had a stress test this past Tuesday and everything was OK. Now this weekend he had another spell of lightheadedness and felt a little dizzy. Any answers as what to do next.

patient_question.phrase: Now this weekend he had another spell of lightheadedness and felt a little dizzy. Any answers as what to do next.

case.clinician_question: What should he do for persistent lightheadedness?
case.note_excerpt: Discharge Instructions: You were admitted to the Neurology service because of left hand clumsiness. We think you had inflamation on the surface of part of your brain. We did not find a specific cause at the time of discharge. There are still some tests pending at discharge and you should follow-up with neurology clinic as scheduled. If you have any new symptoms or high fever, please call the neurology clinic or go to the emergency room.

There are still some tests pending at discharge and you should follow-up with neurology clinic as scheduled.
If you have any new symptoms or high fever, please call the neurology clinic or go to the emergency room.

case.patient_narrative: I vhave a rolling sensation in my head when I lye down.I feel sick to my stomach.I have been treated for high blood pressure for 15 years.My blood pressure generally stays around 117 over 72.About 6 days ago,it began going to 158 over 106 or around there in the evenings.Because it was a weekend ,I took a second 80mg Diovan each evening.On the thrid evening,I went to emergency.They found nothing.On Tuesday I seen an ear,nose,and throat specialist.He only found a problem with "TMJ".I am now taking 200mg of Advil 3 times a day and Soma before bedtime.My blood pressure is 132 over 83 and going up as it gets later.I have moved recently and have no local doctor.Can "TMJ" cause this rise in blood pressure?

patient_question.phrase: Can "TMJ" cause this rise in blood pressure?

case.clinician_question: Is TMJ causing her high blood pressure?
case.note_excerpt:
Brief Hospital Course: Ms. ___ is a ___ yo woman with history of migraines, 2 prior hemorrhagic strokes and severe bilateral carotid stenosis who presents with complaints of acute onset of dizziness.
1. Dizziness. Given Ms. ___ significant vascular history, she was admitted for MRI to rule out a posterior circulation stroke. MRI showed no sign of stroke, and MRA showed preserved posterior circulation. She does have known severe internal carotid disease, but nothing that can be intervened on at this point. She was evaluated by physical therapy, who found her gait to be improved, and that she was safe for discharge home. It was suspected that her symptoms were related to a combination of her peripheral neuropathy, her autonomic instability, and her prior migraines, as she did develop a headache following this event. She will continue to follow-up in the ___ clinic. Exam on discharge was notable for mild gait instability, and bilateral lower extremity peripheral neuropathy.
Discharge Instructions: You were admitted for dizziness. You had an MRI which showed no sign of a new stroke. It is likely that your symptoms were secondary to a migraine. You should continue to take your current medications.
If you notice new weakness, sensory loss, worsening dizziness, or other concerning symptoms, please return to the nearest ED for further evaluation.

case.patient_narrative: my husband fell on sat and we noticed a lump on his clavicle ..took him to hospital did x-ray came back neg ..had a ct scan said it was a lump of tissue. after we left the hospital last night it became very swollen but seems to have went down this morning what caused it and when will it go away..he is still in pain

patient_question.phrase: my husband fell on sat and we noticed a lump on his clavicle
what caused it and when will it go away

case.clinician_question: Why did he get a lump on his chest after he fell and what is the expected course of his recovery?
case.note_excerpt:
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted after a small amount of hemoptysis (coughing up blood). A CAT scan of your chest showed bleeding in your lung. The interventional radiology team did a procedure to get a clear look at the blood vessels in the area and to try to put a clot in the blood vessel to prevent further bleeding. They were not able to reach the right spot without risking making your condition worse, but they were able to tell that it would be safe for the interventional pulmonology team to do a bronchoscopy (look down your windpipe at your lungs from the inside with a camera) and cauterize the area to lower the chance of future bleeding. You underwent both procedures without any difficulty and did not have any further bleeding during your admission.
You also received an MRI of your L shoulder to see what the lump might be - it is a benign (not cancerous) lump of fat. The bone is normal. There is nothing that needs to be done about it today. Please discuss with your primary care doctor if you continue to have pain in the area.
Please notify your oncologist or PCP about the development of ANY new symptoms, most specifically, any increased weakness in the legs, falls, trouble urinating or not urinating, trouble having bowel movements or not having bowel control.
